title: Following the signs: applying urban regime analysis to a UK case study
abstract:
As the debate continues regarding the applicability of urban regime analysis in\ud
a UK context, three aspects stand out as highly significant: the target for analysis, the mode of\ud
scrutiny, and the context of local governing arrangements with its implications for interdependence\ud
as an impetus for co-operation. This article will examine urban regime analysis and the move\ud
from government to governance in order to answer why and how the private, voluntary and public\ud
sectors might be inclined to collaborate in regimes. In addition, the regime analysis will provide the\ud
parameters for examination whilst the issue of governance will afford context for local governing\ud
arrangements. Although some issues require slight reframing to reflect the UK context, the article\ud
will follow a rigorous framework for examination utilizing the full weight of regime analysis as\ud
articulated by Stone such that it could not be accused of “concept stretching.” Far from it: Through\ud
the examination of an informal partnership, a coalition of actors from the public, private, and\ud
voluntary sectors that has been in existence for more than 13 years, the article focuses, specifically,\ud
on the long-term, less visible aspects of local governance. As such, it is able to demonstrate how\ud
economic and political change can have a tangible effect on the manifestation of interdependence as\ud
an impetus for co-operation, not only for this specific locale but also for other cities facing similar\ud
challenges
